Yves Herman - Reuters
Here we follow all developments regarding the growing tension between Russia, Ukraine and the West.
More updates
6:25 pm – Kiev asks the West for more weapons and guarantees of EU membership
Ukraine today urged its Western allies to supply it with more weapons and give it guarantees of future membership in the European Union (EU) to support it against Russia.
"This morning I sent the British Foreign Minister a letter asking for more defensive weapons for Ukraine", declared the Ukrainian Foreign Minister, Dmytro Kuleba, at a press conference at the embassy in Washington, specifying that he will address a similar request to his North American interlocutors.
"We will mobilize the entire world to obtain everything we need to strengthen our defense capacity," he added.
The head of Ukrainian diplomacy also indicated that he had "appealed to the European Union to put aside all hesitation, all reticence and all skepticism that exist in European capitals and to make Ukraine the promise of its future accession".
While welcoming Berlin's "strong" decision to suspend certification of the Russian-German Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline following Moscow's recognition of the independence of Ukraine's breakaway territories, Kuleba called for "more strong sanctions" to weigh on Russia.
"[Russian President Vladimir] Putin's calculation was that his decision would have no consequences. And, in the absence of punishment, the appetite for aggression becomes stronger," he maintained.
6:16 pm – Augusto Santos Silva says that “if Russia persists” it will face more sanctions
At the end of the meeting between the 27 member states in Brussels, the Portuguese Minister of Foreign Affairs told RTP that it had been easy to reach an agreement on sanctions against Russia. “There was a general consensus”, stated Augusto Santos Silva.
“We are facing very serious behavior on the part of Russia”, so “the answer could only be this”, he stressed.
The minister explained that this was only the first package of sanctions, which responds to the acts carried out by Russia on Monday. “These sanctions are already powerful”, he said, adding that “we will ban any financing from the European space of the Russian State, including the Russian Central Bank”.
“But if Russia persists in this aggressive, hostile behavior, which is so clearly in violation of the most basic rules of the international order, we will naturally have to respond with more sanctions,” he added.
Augusto Santos Silva did not want to hide “the enormous concern that this situation raises”, because “there are already official statements from Russia that call into question Ukraine's own independence”.
“We are at a level of disrespect, hostility, that is absolutely unbelievable and unacceptable,” continued the person in charge. “Today is a day to respond firmly to Russia.”
5:51 pm – Boris Johnson spoke to Emmanuel Macron
The British Prime Minister spoke to the French President this afternoon about developments in Ukraine.
"The Prime Minister updated President Macron on the new British sanctions against Russia. The two leaders agreed that they need to continue to work together to sanction Russian individuals and entities that finance President Putin's aggressive approach," said Downing Street in a statement.
Boris Johnson also said that President Putin's actions are a gross violation of international law and that, by sending forces to eastern Ukraine, he has torn up the Budapest and Minsk agreements.
“Russia’s actions not only threaten Ukraine’s sovereignty, they are a blatant attack on freedom and democracy,” the leaders agreed.
“They both agreed to stay in close contact and speak again in the coming days.”
5:45 pm – Moscow announces withdrawal of Russian diplomats from Ukraine
The Russian Government has just announced that it will withdraw its diplomatic staff from Ukraine.
5:42 pm – Germany reinforces troops in Lithuania and Hungary mobilizes on the Ukrainian border
Germany announced today its intention to increase the contingent of soldiers deployed at a NATO base in Lithuania, on the same day that Hungary announced the mobilization of military units in the border areas with Ukraine.
German Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht declared her determination to increase the number of troops "by land, sea and air" during a working visit to Lithuania.
The increase, which has not been quantified, joins another announced weeks ago by Lambrecht and which consists of 350 additional soldiers to the 350 troops that Germany already has in the Baltic country and who are participating in an aerial surveillance mission.
5:33 pm – Russian Parliament approves Putin’s request to send troops abroad
The upper house of the Russian Parliament today approved the president's request to send Russian military personnel abroad, after Vladimir Putin committed to military assistance to pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine.
After an urgent debate, the senate approved this request unanimously among the 153 members.
The Russian president had hours earlier asked for authorization to use military forces outside the country, a move that formalizes a Russian military deployment to rebel regions and could allow a broader attack on Ukraine.
5:24 pm – European Union approves sanctions package against Russia
The 27 Member States of the European Union reached an agreement this Tuesday on a package of sanctions, unanimously approved, to “affect Russia”.
Josep Borrell, senior EU official for Foreign Policy and Security, announced that the decision was taken “in close coordination with partners the United States, United Kingdom and Canada”.
The sanctions package will apply to “351 members of the Duma [lower house of the Russian Federal Assembly] who approved this violation of Ukraine's territorial integrity”.
It will also apply to 27 individuals and entities with a “threatening role for the independence of Ukraine”, announced Borrell.
"But sanctions are only part of our response. Diplomatic efforts will continue", added the official, adding that the EU will send a mission to Ukraine following a request for help from it.
Regarding financial sanctions, restrictions are expected on the EU's economic relations with the two separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, as well as the freezing of assets of two private Russian banks, specified Josep Borrell.
Now follows a meeting of member states' ambassadors to the EU, for the final approval of the sanctions package, later today.
5:11 pm - NATO expects large-scale Russian attack and prepares military forces
NATO expects a large-scale attack from Russia in Ukraine and has put its rapid reaction force on alert to defend allied countries, the Alliance's secretary general announced today.
"Everything suggests that Russia is planning a massive attack in Ukraine", after sending troops to the pro-Russian separatist territories of Donbass, in the east of the country, said Jens Stoltenberg after an extraordinary meeting of the NATO-Ukraine commission, at the Alliance's headquarters in Brussels.
4:56 pm – Almost unanimous condemnation of Moscow and calls for severe sanctions
More than a dozen European countries today condemned Russia's recognition of the independence of separatist territories in Eastern Ukraine as a serious violation of sovereignty, which "will drastically increase tensions" in Europe, says NATO.
The dissonant voices came from Iran, which considers that it was "the provocative actions of NATO, supported by the United States, that complicated the situation in the region", and from Syria, which said today that it intends to strengthen ties with the self-proclaimed separatist republics of Donetsk and Lugansk.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg stated that Russia's recognition of the independence of these two self-proclaimed separatist republics "is a deliberate violation of international law and the Minsk agreements, which drastically increases tensions in Europe", in a message on Twitter.
Poland and other countries neighboring Ukraine, in addition to condemning Moscow's act, call for severe sanctions. Polish Defense Minister Mariusz Blaszczak defends "serious, non-symbolic sanctions" against Moscow, because only in this way will the "return of the Soviet empire" be avoided.
Lithuania spoke in the same sense, through its Minister of Foreign Affairs, Gabrielius Landsbergis, who was one of the most critical voices of Russian maneuvers, calling for unity in European action.
"Russia considers that we are not united, that we will not apply sanctions to them. We will show them that we are and that we can affect them by what they are doing," said Landsbergis, whose country is on the front line of Russian tensions as one of the former members of the USSR.
Slovakia considers Moscow's recognition of the independence of Ukrainian separatist provinces "unacceptable", Slovak Foreign Minister Ivan Korcok said in a statement.
Slovenian Prime Minister Janez Jansa condemned Putin's "illegal act" and proposed that the European Union invite Ukraine to join the community bloc as an effective member.
4:54 pm – EU MNEs prepare strong sanctions package for Russia
European Union (EU) foreign ministers meet this afternoon in Paris to analyze the sanctions that were designed by EU ambassadors.
The sanctions will need unanimous approval, for this, an official meeting could be called for tomorrow, Wednesday, in Brussels, as reported by Antena 1 correspondent, Andrea Neves.
4:38 pm – US applauds German blockade of Russian gas pipeline
The United States today applauded Germany's decision to block the certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline and guaranteed new sanctions against Moscow, following Russia's recognition of separatist territories in eastern Ukraine.
The White House also today began referring to the deployment of Russian troops in eastern Ukraine as an "invasion", after initially hesitating to use the term - a 'red line' that US President Joe Biden said would result in the imposition of severe sanctions on Moscow.
Reacting to the sanctions indicated by Berlin, including the blocking of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline - which would transport gas from Russia to Germany - White House spokeswoman Jen Psaki wrote on the social network Twitter that this is a positive sign of harmony between the United States and European allies in combating Moscow's attitudes in Ukraine.
"We were in close conversations with Germany this morning and welcome their announcement. We will continue with our own measures today," Psaki said.
4:25 pm – NATO announces emergency meeting with Kiev later today
NATO announced an emergency meeting of the ambassadors of the 30 member countries with the representative of Ukraine, later today, following Russia's recognition of the self-proclaimed republics of Donbass.
The secretary general of the Atlantic Alliance, Jens Stoltenberg, will give a press conference at the organization's headquarters in Brussels, after this extraordinary meeting of the NATO-Ukraine commission, where the next steps in seeking to resolve the crisis will be discussed.
4:23 pm – Gas exporting countries say it is difficult to increase volumes significantly
The presidents, prime ministers or ministers of the 11 member countries of the Forum of Gas Exporting Countries (FPEG) met in Doha, at a time when the crisis between Moscow and Western countries over Ukraine is contributing to an increase in prices in the sector, where threats from Russia regarding supply also loom.
During the summit, Russian Energy Minister Nikolai Shulginov assured that Moscow is committed "to fulfilling existing contracts", without making any comment on the situation in his country or the crisis in relations with Western countries.
"We appreciate the efforts of all (FPEG) members who have worked hard to ensure a credible and reliable supply of natural gas to the world market and to preserve the stability of these markets," Qatar's Emir, Tamim ben Hamad Al-Thani, told participants at the meeting.
Qatar's Energy Minister, Saad al-Kaabi, stated, for his part, that Qatar, one of the main gas exporters, assured Europe of its help in case of difficulties in supply, specifying, however, that it would be limited to available volumes, since producers are linked to "long-term contracts".
"The volumes that can be redirected (to other customers) represent around 10 to 15%", he pointed out. "Russia represents 30 to 40% of supplies to Europe" and "quickly replacing this type of volume is almost impossible", he added.
4:02 pm – Russia says it does not intend to deploy troops to Donetsk and Luhansk for now
Russia does not currently plan to deploy troops to the separatist republics of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, despite having signed a mutual assistance treaty with the two pro-Russian territories, a Russian official declared today.
"We are not going to speculate. At the moment, we are not planning to send anything anywhere," Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Rudenko told Russian news agency Interfax when asked about sending possible military aid to Donetsk and Lugansk.
Rudenko pointed out that Russia may resort to sending troops, based on the mutual assistance treaty ratified today by the parties, if a threat against Donetsk and Lugansk arises.
"If there is a threat, we will of course provide assistance in accordance with the treaty that has been ratified," Rudenko said.
The texts of the bilateral agreements between Moscow and the two separatist republics also imply joint protection of their borders with Russia and the possibility of using military bases and military infrastructure.
3:22 pm – Kremlin hopes delay in Nord Stream 2 will be temporary
The Kremlin this Tuesday regretted Germany's suspension of certification of the Nord Stream 2 Baltic Sea gas pipeline project. The project aims to double the flow of Russian gas that goes directly to Ukraine.
Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov expects the suspension of certification, in response to Moscow's recent moves, to be temporary.
3:12 pm – Pressure on the European economy
Paolo Gentiloni, European Commissioner for Economy, considers that the new context of conflict in eastern Ukraine puts "strong" pressure on the European Union's economic growth.
"Uncertainty remains around us and the violation of international law through Russian recognition of two separatist territories in Ukraine will greatly increase this uncertainty," said the official.
The European Commissioner pointed out that, in the winter interim macroeconomic forecasts, there was a revision "downwards for this year and upwards in relation to 2023" of the EU's economic growth.
"GDP in the EU is now expected to increase by 4% in 2022 and 2.8% in 2023", highlighted Paolo Gentiloni, admitting however that these estimates were made before the increase in geopolitical tensions regarding the Russian offensive in Ukraine.
3:03 pm – Russians and Ukrainians living in Portugal are worried
The Russian and Ukrainian communities in Portugal are concerned about Vladimir Putin's movements. They feel that they are all "in the same boat" and that war is near.
2:55 pm - Russia puts the issue of the borders of separatist regions on the table
A day after recognizing the separatist regions in eastern Ukraine, Moscow indicated through the Interfax agency that the border issue will have to be resolved in the future.
Also this Tuesday, a separatist leader supported by Russia said that the Kremlin formally recognizes the separatist regions taking into account the wider borders of the Donetsk region, even though a large part of this same region continues to be controlled by Ukrainian forces.
2:44 pm - Portuguese MNE accuses Russia of an "illegitimate and illegal" act and reaffirms support for Ukraine
At the entrance to the meeting of Foreign Ministers in Paris, Augusto Santos Silva reinforced the Portuguese government's solidarity with Ukraine and condemned the actions of the Russian federation.
2:35 pm – Germany says it is ready to send more troops to Lithuania
Germany is "ready" to send more troops to Lithuania in the context of the crisis in Ukraine, Federal Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht said on Tuesday during a visit to the Baltic country.
"We are counting on a diplomatic solution to the Russian crisis. But this requires reliable military deterrence," added the minister, referring to the NATO response force at the Rukla military base, led by Germany.
Recently, due to the tense situation with Russia, Germany decided to increase the contingent in Lithuania from 550 to around 900 soldiers.
2:31 pm – Explosions in Donetsk
Reuters reports this afternoon that six explosions were heard in the center of the city of Donetsk, controlled by pro-Russian separatists.
The origin of the explosions is not clear, but a diplomatic source told Reuters that shelling had resumed on the line of contact between the Ukrainian military and separatist forces in eastern Ukraine.
2:12 pm – Where are NATO forces in Europe?
The Atlantic Alliance is at the center of the current crisis in eastern Ukraine, with Moscow demanding guarantees over the past few months that Kiev would never be part of the organization. But after all, how are NATO forces positioned in relation to Russian territory?
1:40 pm – United Kingdom says it is “inconceivable” that Russia will host the Champions League final
UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson believes Russia should not be allowed to host this season's Champions League final after recognizing the breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine.
The final is scheduled for May in the city of Saint Petersburg.
"I find it inconceivable that major international football tournaments could take place in Russia after the invasion of a sovereign country," said Boris Johnson.
1:36 pm – Hungary will send military personnel to the border with Ukraine
Hungary announced this Tuesday that it will send some troops to the border area with Ukraine. The objective is to prepare a humanitarian mission but also to defend the country's borders.
"Hungary's security is the most important thing, we are strengthening the Ukraine-Hungary border," confirmed the Ministry of Defense on the government's official Facebook page.
13:17 – Which regions are at stake?
Russian President Vladimir Putin announced yesterday that the country would recognize two separatist regions in eastern Ukraine: Donetsk and Luhansk are in eastern Ukraine and are located in a strategic area.
Donetsk and Luhansk
They are the two regions that declared themselves independent republics of Ukraine in 2014.
Divided between the Kiev government and the pro-Russians, they are part of the province of Donbass, on the eastern border with Russia, which is the most populous region in Ukraine.
12:53 pm – United Kingdom applies sanctions to five Russian banks and three oligarchs
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced this Tuesday that the United Kingdom will sanction five Russian banks and three high-net-worth individuals, including billionaire businessman Gennady Timchenko, after Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized two separatist regions in eastern Ukraine.
"Today, the United Kingdom will sanction the following five Russian banks: Rossiya, IS Bank, General Bank, Promsvyazbank and Black Sea Bank, and we are also sanctioning three very high net worth individuals," Johnson announced in the British Parliament.
Boris Johnson said it was time for the world to prepare for the next possible steps in Russian President Vladimir Putin's plan for Ukraine, after Moscow sent Russian forces to the two separatist regions in the east of the country.
"The House should be in no doubt that the deployment of these forces on sovereign Ukrainian territory represents a further invasion of that country," Johnon told the House of Commons, the lower house of the British Parliament.
"We must now prepare for the next possible steps of Putin's plan: the violent subversion of areas of eastern Ukraine by Russian agents and their mercenaries, followed by a general offensive by the nearly 200,000 Russian troops massed on the borders, at the height of their readiness to attack," Johnson said.
12:46 pm – European sanctions will be announced later this Tuesday
In a statement on the social network Twitter, the president of the European Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, announced that "a first package of sanctions [against Russia] will be formally presented today".
Russia's aggression against Ukraine is illegal and unacceptable.
The Union remains united in its support for Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity.
A first package of sanctions will be formally tabled today.
— Ursula von der Leyen (@vonderleyen)
February 22, 2022
"Russia's aggressiveness against Ukraine is illegal and unacceptable. The [European] Union remains united in support of Ukrainian sovereignty and territorial integrity," writes von der Leyen.
To the Lusa agency, European sources indicated that the "first package of restrictive measures was presented today at COREPER II [Committee of Permanent Representatives of the Governments of the Member States of the European Union]", covering a "list of 27 entities", as well as "names of members of the Duma", the lower house of the Russian Federal Assembly (parliament), in a total of around 350.
The same sources specified that, with regard to financial sanctions, "the European Commission will propose restrictions on the economic relations of the European Union (EU) with the two" separatist regions, Donetsk and Lugansk, with the "freezing of assets of two private Russian banks".
These sanctions will still have to be approved by Member States. This afternoon, the European Union's foreign ministers will analyze, in an informal urgent meeting in Paris, the imposition of these sanctions on Russia.
A new meeting of the member states' ambassadors to the EU (COREPER II) is also scheduled for the end of the day, for the final approval of this sanctions package.
12:28 pm – Ukraine welcomes Germany’s decision on Nord Stream 2
Dmytro Kuleba, Ukrainian Minister of Foreign Affairs, said this Tuesday that the decision to suspend certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline is a "morally and politically correct" step in the current circumstances.
"True leadership means difficult decisions in difficult times. Germany's decision proves this," said the Ukrainian MNE.
12:23 pm – Marcelo says that the step taken by Russia “speaks for itself”
"The situation speaks for itself, the step that was taken speaks for itself, and the reaction also spoke for itself, by pointing out, on the one hand, what was a clear violation of the Minsk Agreements and, on the other hand, questioning the territorial integrity of Ukraine", said the Portuguese President in a statement to journalists from The Hague, Netherlands.
Asked about the European Union's reaction and Portugal's position regarding sanctions aimed at Moscow, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa declined to "anticipate what decisions will be taken and scenarios subsequent to these decisions", stating that it is necessary to "wait for European deliberations".
12:15 pm – Gas supply to Germany is not in question but prices could rise, says the German Economy Minister
Robert Habeck, German Vice Chancellor and Economy Minister, guaranteed this Tuesday that the supply of natural gas is assured even without Nord Stream 2.
The new pipeline would have the capacity to double the amount of Russian gas reaching Germany.
The German government official warned, however, that gas prices are "another issue", which indicates a possible abrupt rise in prices in the short term.
12:07 pm - European Commission says that interruption of Nord Stream 2 will not affect energy supply to Europe
At a press conference, a spokesperson for the European Commission highlighted this Tuesday that Nord Stream 2 "is not yet operating, it is not supplying energy to Europe", and that therefore there are no changes to the current situation.
11:46 am - Amnesty International calls for the protection of the civilian population
In a statement, Amnesty International's Secretary General, Agnès Callamard, said that the protection of civilians in Ukraine must be the "absolute priority" of all parties involved.
"While the potential for all-out conflict is now a devastating reality, every effort must be made to minimize civilian suffering and prioritize humanity in this crisis. It is a legal obligation on all parties," he stressed.
11:40 am – Reactions in Portugal. PSD condemns Russia's decision
In a statement, the Social Democrats consider that this is "a violation of international law, the Minsk agreements and the principle of respect for the territorial integrity of States."
"No international order can survive when States feel free to call into question the sovereignty of other States and to change borders by force", highlights the PSD's national permanent commission.
11:10 am – Germany suspends authorization for the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline
German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced this Tuesday that the certification of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline cannot proceed given the recent actions taken by Russia.
The controversial gas pipeline connects Russia to Germany and was built to take Russian gas to the country
European.
"In light of the latest developments, we should re-evaluate the situation in particular regarding Nord Stream 2," said Scholz.
11:01 am – Kremlin says it is “open” to diplomacy
The Kremlin said this Tuesday that it remains available for diplomacy with the West. "Russia remains open to diplomatic contacts at all levels, the Russian side is interested in this," Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told the press, emphasizing that "contacts at the highest level, even emergency ones, must be well prepared."
10:56 am – Kiev plans to cut ties with Moscow
RTP's correspondent in Moscow, Evgueni Mouravitch, says that both chambers of the Russian Parliament are meeting in plenary sessions to approve Vladimir Putin's agreements on the separatist republics.
The Ukrainian president plans to completely cut off diplomatic relations with Russia and, on the economic front, Moscow is already suffering the consequences of the decision to recognize the separatist republics.
In the Russian capital, citizens feel frustrated and tired regarding the crisis with Ukraine.
The RTP correspondent also recalls the example of the Russian recognition, in 2008, of South Ossetia, a region that is part of Georgia.
10:52 am – Lavrov questions Ukraine’s right to sovereignty
This Tuesday, the Russian MNE questioned Ukraine's right to sovereignty, considering that the Kiev Government does not represent the constituent parts of the country.
Sergei Lavrov accuses Ukraine of not respecting international law since 2014, when the pro-Russian president was overthrown by Kiev and replaced by a pro-Western leader, which led to the annexation of Crimea and the start of war in the eastern regions.
"I don't think anyone can claim that the Ukrainian regime, since the 2014 coup d'état, represents all people living on the territory of the Ukrainian state," said the head of Russian diplomacy.
10:37 am – Sanctions on separatist republics are seen as a “joke” in Kiev
RTP's special envoy to Kiev, Cândida Pinto, tells us what the atmosphere was like this Tuesday in the capital of Ukraine. In the country, the sanctions announced for the separatist republics are being disregarded, as they are economically depressed areas and have been in conflict over the last eight years.
The Ukrainians want to see stronger sanctions, immediately applied to Moscow and Putin and demand, for example, the cancellation of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline.
10:22 am – Erdogan condemns recognition of separatist regions
Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan said recognition of Ukraine's two breakaway regions was "unacceptable" and called on all parties to respect international laws.
Turkey is a member of NATO and a maritime neighbor of Ukraine and Russia across the Black Sea, maintaining some diplomatic proximity with both countries. Erdogan has already made himself available to mediate the conflict, but today he warned of the danger of a Russian invasion and criticized the way the West handled the crisis.
"We see this decision by Russia as unacceptable. We repeat our call for common sense and respect for international law on all sides," said the Turkish president.
9:59 am – Sanctions are predictable, says the Russian MNE
Sergei Lavrov, Russian Foreign Minister, said Western-imposed sanctions would be imposed "with or without a reason."
"Our European, North American and British colleagues will not stop, they will not calm down, until they have exhausted all their possibilities of punishing Russia. They are already threatening us with all types of sanctions and now they are even talking about the 'mother of all sanctions'. Well, we are used to it. We know that sanctions will be imposed anyway and in any case, with or without a reason", says the person in charge, quoted by Reuters.
9:54 am – The issue of Russian gas
In a letter sent to an energy conference in Doha, Russian President Vladimir Putin assured that Moscow will continue to supply natural gas to world markets despite the crisis.
9:48 am - "Another step towards the restoration of the Soviet Union"
Russia's decision to recognize two breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine means the Kremlin is taking "another step" in restoring the Soviet Union, Ukrainian Defense Minister Oleksii Reznikov said on Tuesday.
"The Kremlin has taken another step towards the restoration of the Soviet Union. With a new Warsaw Pact and a new Berlin Wall", says the government official in a statement.
9:43 am – The impact of the crisis in the east on exports and the economy
Russian recognition of the independence of separatist regions of Ukraine is triggering a series of sanctions from the United States and the European Union. But the opposite could also happen, which could mean the end of meat and oil exports from the Russian market, which serve global interests.
Bilateral cuts that are already being felt and will cause strong impacts on the financial markets. Pedro Sousa Carvalho, Economy commentator for Antena 1, warns of the
consequences of an escalation of conflict in the real economy
. An example of this is the European stock markets registering daily falls.
As the crisis deepens, a barrel of oil could reach 150 dollars, which will have strong implications for final consumer prices and the transport sector. The case of natural gas could be even more serious, since 35 percent of Europe's imports come from Russia.
However, Pedro Sousa Carvalho recalls that the Russians never completely closed the tap to Europe, not even during the Cold War.
9:39 am - Czech Republic says it is prepared for cuts in energy supply and flow of refugees
Speaking in Parliament, the Prime Minister of the Czech Republic, Petr Fiala, said this Tuesday that the country is prepared for several scenarios, including the potential interruption of energy supplies by Russia and the arrival of refugees from Ukraine.
9:25 am - "This is without a doubt one of the darkest days in European history"
Frans Timmermans, vice-president of the European Commission, considered that today is "undoubtedly one of the darkest days in European history". In statements from the European Union's Indo-Pacific forum in Paris, the official accuses Russia of a "flagrant act of disrespect for the rule of law and international law".
"Russia can no longer dominate and therefore chooses to disrupt. Our reaction to this behavior will determine not only Europe's security, but also global security in the coming years", said Timmermans.
9:09 am – “Putin is an autocrat”
Speaking to RTP, Nunes Barata, former Portuguese ambassador to Moscow, considers that Vladimir Putin "is an autocrat". "Autocrats don't like negotiating, they are more in favor of creating crises to see if they can take advantage of them", he adds.
8:47 am – The main moments of the emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council
The United Nations Security Council met this morning in emergency at the request of Ukraine.
Linda Thomas-Greenfield, United States ambassador to the United Nations, condemns Russia and states that the decision to recognize the independence of the separatist regions of Ukraine is a return to a time before the UN.
China called for a peaceful solution and defended a diplomatic resolution of the conflict. Zhang Jun, Beijing's ambassador to the UN, says "all countries should resolve international disputes through peaceful means"
The United Kingdom accuses Russia of total disregard for international law. "By seeking to forcibly redraw borders, Russia's actions show a blatant disregard for international law," said Barbara Woodward, British ambassador to the organization.
On the French side, Ambassador Nicolas de Rivière called on Moscow to stop all actions that threaten the lives of populations and other acts of destabilization. "France will continue to mobilize in support of Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity within its internationally recognized borders," he added.
At this emergency meeting, Ukraine's ambassador to the UN, Sergiy Kyslytsya, stated that the current configuration of Ukraine's borders is to be maintained. He further considered that "all members of the United Nations are under attack".
"We are in our land, we are not afraid of anything or anyone. We owe nothing to anyone and we will not give anything to anyone", he added.
Russia's ambassador to the United Nations says that Moscow is available for a diplomatic solution, but emphasizes that the country limited itself to recognizing two areas that did not want to be part of Ukraine.
Vasily Nebenzya blames Western countries, led by the United States: "In addition to creating baseless panic over the last few weeks around the alleged Russian invasion of Ukraine, our Western colleagues have shamelessly filled the country with weapons."
8:43 am – EU does not classify entry of Russian troops into Ukraine as an invasion
"Russian troops entered Donbass. We consider Donbass to be part of Ukraine. I wouldn't say it's a complete invasion, but Russian troops are on Ukrainian soil," said the European Union's High Representative for Foreign Policy, Joseph Borrell.
8:39 - "I'm not afraid." President of Ukraine accuses Russia of never seeking peace
Volodymyr Zelensky stated that he is in contact with his European allies, from whom he expects "clear" and "effective" support, and with the United Nations.
He also promised to do everything to achieve a calm resolution that respects both parties. In a message to Moscow, he added that Ukraine "is no longer the same as it was in 2014", when it lost the Crimean Peninsula.
"We are in our home and we do not owe anything to anyone nor are we going to hand over anything to anyone," said the President, after accusing Russia of violating Ukrainian sovereignty.
"I'm not afraid of anything or anyone", underlined Volodymyr Zelenskyi.
8:34 am – Celebrations in Donetsk welcome Russian recognition of independence
In the Donetsk region, the population reacted with celebrations to the recognition of the sovereignty of the two separatist regions of Ukraine. Fireworks, horns and lots of chanting marked the night in Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine, with Russian flags many celebrating Vladimir Putin's decision in the streets.
8:16 am – The invasion of Ukraine has begun, says the United Kingdom
British Health Minister Sajid Javid claims that the invasion of Ukraine has already begun and that Vladimir Putin has decided to attack the country's sovereignty.
“We are waking up to a very dark day in Europe and it is clear, from what we have seen and discovered today, that the Russians and President Putin have decided to attack Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity”, said the official, quoted by Reuters.
Speaking to Sky News television, Sajid Javid stated that the current situation is as worrying for the world as the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. At the time, the United States and the Soviet Union were on the brink of a nuclear war.
"I think it's as serious a situation as this," he considered.
He also added that British Prime Minister Boris Johnson
should give a speech in Parliament about Ukraine, this
Tuesday.
"We saw that he [Putin] recognized these separatist regions in eastern Ukraine and from the reports we can already say that he sent tanks and troops. From this information, we can conclude that the invasion of Ukraine has begun," said the minister.
7:43 am – Status update
The United Nations Security Council met this morning, on an emergency basis, at the request of Ukraine: a rare nighttime meeting requested by Kiev and several European countries, hours after the Russian President recognized the independence of Donetsk and Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky
accuses Russia
of breaking with the agreements made between the two countries and of being solely responsible for the current situation.
These are two pro-Russian separatist regions that do not want to be part of Ukraine. Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision is being seen as opening the door to a large-scale invasion of Ukraine.
The next few hours will be decisive in understanding what Russia wants to achieve.
Ukraine's ambassador to the UN, Sergiy Kyslytsya, stated that his country's borders will not change. In turn, Russia's ambassador to the UN, Vasily Nebenzya, claims to be available for a diplomatic solution. But he claims that Russia merely recognized two areas that did not want to be part of Ukraine.
Sanctions underway
The American president has already moved forward with sanctions on Russia. Joe Biden banned trade with the regions of Donetsk and Luhansk, which Russia assumed to be independent from Ukraine.
The President of the United States signed an executive order prohibiting new investment, trade and financing by American citizens or companies to and from the two Ukrainian regions. And he also admits moving forward with more sanctions.
Russian President Vladimir Putin claims that, historically, Ukraine is part of the Russian empire. And he states that, in the current context, Russia feels threatened.
The European Union could move forward with sanctions on Russia this Tuesday.
European reactions manifested themselves immediately, after the Russian president signed the decrees recognizing the independence of the two regions led by pro-Russian separatists.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen condemned Russia on behalf of the entire Union.
Russian forces in eastern Ukraine
Russian troops will have already entered eastern Ukraine.
According to the Reuters agency, close to a dozen unmarked tanks entered Donetsk, shortly after Putin's decision.
The Russian president has also ordered the Ministry of Defense to send what Moscow describes as Russian "peacekeeping forces" to the two separatist regions.
What is at stake
At the center of the tension are two territories: Donetsk and Lugansk, in eastern Ukraine, border areas with Russia.
The two territories were occupied by pro-Russian rebels, with support and encouragement so far not provided by Moscow.
This situation paves the way for the Russian army to enter Ukraine, because now Moscow can claim that the army is advancing at the request of those territories to which it has recognized autonomy.
At the moment, Ukraine is threatened from the north, east and south and almost surrounded, which has put the country and the West on alert.
The Portuguese position
The Portuguese Prime Minister reacted on Twitter.
“Russian recognition of the two separatist regions of Ukraine violates the Minsk agreements and calls into question the territorial integrity of Ukraine,” wrote António Costa.
The Prime Minister adds that the Government "strongly condemns this action and expresses full solidarity with Ukraine".
The President of the Republic also condemned the Kremlin's decision. Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa guarantees that Portugal is monitoring the situation to safeguard the Portuguese in Ukraine and the Ukrainians living in Portugal.

O Reino Unido anunciou hoje sanções contra três oligarcas conhecidos por serem próximos do Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, e contra cinco bancos russos, em retaliação ao reconhecimento de Moscovo das regiões separatistas de Lugansk e Donetsk, no leste ucraniano.
Os multimilionários visados são Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg e o sobrinho deste último, Igor Rotenberg, revelou o primeiro-ministro britânico, Boris Johnson, no Parlamento.
Johnson avisou ter outras sanções "prontas" para serem introduzidas juntamente com os Estados Unidos e a União Europeia (UE) se o conflito continuar a escalar.
"Esta é a primeira parcela, a primeira carga do que estamos preparados para fazer e temos mais sanções prontas para serem impostas", afirmou.
O pacote de sanções foi anunciado depois de uma reunião de emergência de ministros e altos funcionários, realizada hoje de manhã, no chamado comité de segurança Cobra.
A ministra dos Negócios Estrangeiros, Liz Truss, adiantou também que o embaixador da Rússia no Reino Unido, Andrei Kelin, foi chamado "para explicar a violação do direito internacional pela Rússia e o desrespeito à soberania da Ucrânia".
O chefe do Governo britânico disse aos deputados antecipar uma "longa crise" na Ucrânia tendo em conta que Putin ordenou o envio de tropas para alegadas operações de "manutenção da paz" nas regiões de Donetsk e Lugansk.
"Não posso dizer o que acontecerá nos próximos dias, mas devemos esperar uma longa crise", disse Boris Johnson.
Em 2014, a Rússia anexou a península ucraniana da Crimeia, depois da queda do Governo pró-russo em Kiev, e elaborou um referendo sobre o regresso do território à Federação Russa. Desde então, Kiev está em conflito com separatistas pró-russos no leste do país.
A guerra no leste da Ucrânia entre as forças de Kiev e separatistas pró-Rússia fizeram até ao momento mais de 14 mil mortos, de acordo com as Nações Unidas.
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, assinou, na segunda-feira à noite, um decreto que reconhece as regiões separatistas de Lugansk e de Donetsk, no Donbass (leste), e ordenou a entrada das forças armadas russas naqueles territórios ucranianos numa missão de "manutenção da paz".
A decisão de Putin foi condenada pela generalidade dos países ocidentais, que já anunciaram ou estão a preparar sanções económicas contra a Rússia.

The United Kingdom today announced sanctions against three oligarchs known to be close to Russian President Vladimir Putin and against five Russian banks, in retaliation for Moscow's recognition of the separatist regions of Luhansk and Donetsk, in eastern Ukraine.
The targeted billionaires are Gennady Timchenko, Boris Rotenberg and the latter's nephew, Igor Rotenberg, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson revealed in Parliament.
Johnson warned he has other sanctions "ready" to be introduced alongside the United States and the European Union (EU) if the conflict continues to escalate.

"I can't say what will happen in the next few days, but we must expect a long crisis," said Boris Johnson.
In 2014, Russia annexed the Ukrainian peninsula of Crimea, after the fall of the pro-Russian government in Kiev, and held a referendum on the return of the territory to the Russian Federation. Since then, Kiev has been in conflict with pro-Russian separatists in the east of the country.
The war in eastern Ukraine between Kiev forces and pro-Russian separatists has so far killed more than 14,000 people, according to the United Nations.
Russian President Vladimir Putin signed, on Monday night, a decree recognizing the separatist regions of Lugansk and Donetsk, in the Donbass (east), and ordered the entry of Russian armed forces into those Ukrainian territories in a "peacekeeping" mission.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, which have already announced or are preparing economic sanctions against Russia.

21 fev, 2022 - 23:42 •
José Bastos
Reconhecer as repúblicas pró-russas é a jogada mais recente de Putin na partida de xadrez que mantém com Biden. O trunfo de 2022, como a Crimeia, agora inegociável, foi em 2014 ou, antes, a Ossétia do Sul e a Abecásia.

No imprevisível tabuleiro ucraniano,
a decisão de Putin
de reconhecer como países independentes as duas auto-proclamadas repúblicas de Donetsk e Lugansk,
além de representar, na prática, o fim dos acordos de Minsk de 2015, pode antecipar o início de uma operação militar em larga escala
. O reconhecimento chega depois de semanas de tensão, com 180 mil soldados russos rodeando a fronteira da Ucrânia e com a ameaça da invasão a impender em cima da mesa.
Não se trata de uma decisão totalmente inesperada.
Putin já havia aludido, a semana passada, a alegados ataques à sua população e na reunião desta segunda-feira do Conselho de Segurança em Moscovo, como seria antecipável, todas as intervenções foram no sentido de satisfazer as exigências dos líderes separatistas
, favorecendo o reconhecimento de Donetsk e Lugansk como estados independentes.
Na ronda de intervenções no Conselho de Segurança russo, o mais explícito foi o ex-presidente e ex-primeiro ministro Dmitri Medvedv, “sabemos o que acontecerá se as repúblicas de Donetsk e Lugansk forem reconhecidas. A pressão será ilimitada, mas saberemos resistir. Na opinião de Medvedv, “O Ocidente pedirá para regressar ao diálogo sobre segurança estratégica se a Rússia apoia o Donbass, como já sucedeu em 2008, tendo em conta a intervenção russa na Ossétia do Sul e Abecásia”. Afinal, a referência a um cenário idêntico, o reconhecimento das regiões separatistas da Geórgia, causando como a guerra de agosto russo-georgiana, o primeiro grande momento de deterioração da relação da Rússia com o Ocidente, desde o final da guerra fria.

Dmitri Kózak, representante do Kremlin no “grupo de contacto” que negoceia a aplicação dos acordos de Minsk, também veio dizer “ser evidente que Ucrânia e os seus aliados ocidentais não necessitam de Donbass em nenhuma circunstância. Kózak também foi da opinião de que “as negociações dos acordos de Minsk estão no grau zero desde 2015”.
Fim dos acordos de Minsk e primeiro passo para uma posterior anexação ou a conversão em protetorados russos? A decisão de hoje é a sequência do levantamento em armas das províncias de Donetsk e Lugansk, depois da revolução da Euromaidán que derrubou a presidência de Viktor Yanukóvich. Havia sido a resposta do Kremlin à saída do poder dos oligarcas pró-russos a mandar em Kiev, desde o fim da URSS. Desde 2014, Donetsk e Lugansk estavam controladas pela milícia Nova Rússia. Donetsk e Lugansk são, nesse sentido, os trunfos mais recentes de Putin na partida de xadrez que mantém com Biden, como a Crimeia o foi em 2014.
Para Moscovo, a Crimeia é agora inegociável. Apesar dos protestos e da violação do direito internacional é um cenário diferente de Donetsk e Lugansk.
Pode a Crimeia formar parte de um entendimento com múltiplas variáveis? Que, entre as possibilidades, a Ucrânia admita a soberania russa em troca de que Moscovo aceite a integridade territorial ucraniana nas fonteiras atuais, Donetsk e Lugansk incluídas, no regresso a Minsk 2? A exigência de que Moscovo não abdicaria seria o congelamento da aproximação da Ucrânia à NATO.
Mas o conjunto de dúvidas na sequência do propagandístico reconhecimento de Donestsk e Lugansk de uma independência que não é real de territórios tutelados por Moscovo desde 2014, não se esgota na reação a aguardar da Casa Branca. É a crise da Ucrânia o maior aviso para a Europa desde o final da guerra fria? Serve a NATO os interesses das democracias europeias num mundo que deixou de ser bipolar? É que além do jogo de xadrez Putin/Biden, há outro em curso, a opor os Estados Unidos à China.
Já
Putin não terá interesse em que os europeus interfiram no confronto com Biden
(visto de Moscovo, o duelo é entre duas super-potências e não admite intermediários),
mas a realidade é que o grosso dos membros da União Europeia é, ao mesmo tempo, de aliados na NATO
. Países a ser afetados em pleno na sua política, economia e segurança por um conflito na sua fronteira oriental.
Da Europa também se espera maior presença e influência diplomática para oferecer uma alternativa para desativar a crise e ‘destrunfar’ a última jogada de Putin: Donetsk e Lugansk.

On the unpredictable Ukrainian board,
Putin's decision
to recognize the two self-proclaimed republics of Donetsk and Lugansk as independent countries,
In addition to representing, in practice, the end of the 2015 Minsk agreements, it could bring forward the start of a large-scale military operation
. The recognition comes after weeks of tension, with 180,000 Russian soldiers surrounding the Ukrainian border and the threat of invasion looming large.
This is not a completely unexpected decision.
Putin had already alluded, last week, to alleged attacks on his population and at this Monday's Security Council meeting in Moscow, as expected, all interventions were aimed at satisfying the demands of the separatist leaders.
, favoring the recognition of Donetsk and Luhansk as independent states.
In the round of interventions in the Russian Security Council, the most explicit was the former president and former prime minister Dmitri Medvedv, "we know what will happen if the republics of Donetsk and Lugansk are recognized. The pressure will be unlimited, but we will know how to resist. In Medvedv's opinion, "The West will ask to return to the dialogue on strategic security if Russia supports Donbass, as already happened in 2008, taking into account the Russian intervention in South Ossetia and Abkhazia.” After all, the reference to an identical scenario, the recognition of the separatist regions of Georgia, causing the Russian-Georgian August War, the first major moment of deterioration in Russia's relationship with the West, since the end of the cold war.

Dmitri Kózak, Kremlin representative in the “contact group” that negotiates the implementation of the Minsk agreements, also said “it is clear that Ukraine and its Western allies do not need Donbass under any circumstances. Kózak was also of the opinion that “the negotiations of the Minsk agreements have been at zero since 2015”.
End of the Minsk agreements and first step towards subsequent annexation or conversion into Russian protectorates? Today's decision follows the uprising in arms in the provinces of Donetsk and Luhansk, after the Euromaidán revolution that overthrew the presidency of Viktor Yanukovych. It had been the Kremlin's response to the departure from power of the pro-Russian oligarchs ruling in Kiev since the end of the USSR. Since 2014, Donetsk and Lugansk were controlled by the New Russia militia. Donetsk and Lugansk are, in this sense, Putin's most recent trump cards in the chess game he is playing with Biden, as Crimea was in 2014.
For Moscow, Crimea is now non-negotiable. Despite the protests and violation of international law, it is a different scenario from Donetsk and Luhansk.
Can Crimea form part of a multi-variable understanding? That, among the possibilities, Ukraine admits Russian sovereignty in exchange for Moscow accepting Ukrainian territorial integrity at the current borders, Donetsk and Lugansk included, upon return to Minsk 2? The demand that Moscow would not abdicate would be the freezing of Ukraine's approach to NATO.
But the set of doubts following the propagandistic recognition by Donestsk and Lugansk of an independence that is not real for territories protected by Moscow since 2014, does not end in the reaction expected from the White House. Is the Ukraine crisis the biggest warning for Europe since the end of the cold war? Does NATO serve the interests of European democracies in a world that is no longer bipolar? In addition to the Putin/Biden chess game, there is another one underway, pitting the United States against China.
Already
Putin will not be interested in Europeans interfering in the confrontation with Biden
(viewed from Moscow, the duel is between two superpowers and does not admit intermediaries),
but the reality is that the bulk of the European Union's members are, at the same time, NATO allies
. Countries being fully affected in their politics, economy and security by a conflict on their eastern border.
Europe is also expected to have a greater presence and diplomatic influence to offer an alternative to defuse the crisis and 'destroy' Putin's latest move: Donetsk and Lugansk.

title: Rússia faz soar os tambores da guerra na Ucrânia
original_title: Rússia faz soar os tambores da guerra na Ucrânia
translated_title: Russia sounds the drums of war in Ukraine
original_text:
Análise
Rússia faz soar os tambores da guerra na Ucrânia
Putin anunciou, ao final da tarde de segunda-feira, o reconhecimento da independência de duas regiões separatistas na Ucrânia
Foto: EPA

Rafael Barbosa

Rafael Barbosa

Twitter

Comentar
O dia começou com promessas de paz e acabou com o som dos tambores de guerra. Emmanuel Macron esteve quase a conseguir uma cimeira entre Putin e Biden, mas o presidente russo impôs um guião bastante diferente. Poucas horas depois do estertor da diplomacia, reconheceu a independência das duas regiões separatistas do ​​​​​​​Leste da Ucrânia e ordenou o envio de tropas para as regiões Donetsk e Lugansk.
O envio do exército russo para a Ucrânia é, nas palavras de
Vladimir Putin
, uma
"operação de manutenção de paz"
. Não se sabe quantos dos cerca de 200 mil militares estacionados junto à fronteira da Ucrânia (na
Rússia
e na
Bielorrússia
) receberam ordem de marcha. E também não se sabe com que objetivo final: se vão apenas assegurar a "paz" na parte do Donbass ucraniano já controlado pelos separatistas, se avançam para a conquista do território das autoproclamadas repúblicas populares de
Donetsk
e
Lugansk
ainda em poder do exército ucraniano. Pode ser a diferença entre começar ou não de imediato a contagem de mortes.
Alerte-se para a o curto tempo de vida de qualquer notícia ou análise, no que diz respeito ao conflito da Ucrânia. Bastarão os primeiros tiros para que tudo volte a mudar. Como o demonstram as últimas 24 horas. Que até começaram com uma renovada promessa de paz, ou pelo menos de negociação, no seguimento dos esforços do presidente francês. Macron ocupou a noite de domingo e a madrugada de segunda-feira em sucessivos telefonemas para
Vladimir Putin
, depois para
Joe Biden
, e de novo para o autocrata russo.
No final, e ainda na madrugada de segunda-feira, Paris anunciou que
estava em marcha uma cimeira sobre a segurança europeia
, tendo como protagonistas principais os líderes das duas superpotências militares (e apenas isso, uma vez que, em termos económicos, a
Rússia
vale bastante menos do que uma meia dúzia de países e incomparavelmente menos do que os
EUA
). As trompetas da paz soaram por pouco tempo. À desconfiança americana,
sucedeu o alerta russo: é prematuro falar numa cimeira
. Percebeu-se umas horas depois que o guião já estava escrito. E que Putin não pretendia desviar-se nem um milímetro dos seus jogos de guerra.
O momento mais significativo do dia acabaria por ser a reunião do Conselho Nacional de Segurança da Rússia. Uma evidente encenação, alegadamente em direto para a televisão (jornalistas que assistiram em direto admitem como bastante provável a hipótese de ter sido um momento previamente gravado), que serviu sobretudo para o autocrata russo comprometer os membros mais importantes do seu Governo com o que se iria seguir.
Com maior ou menor entusiasmo, figuras como Dimitri Medvedev (que alternou, às ordens de Putin, nos lugares de primeiro-ministro e presidente, até este ter conseguido as alterações constitucionais que o eternizam no poder), a presidente da Duma (o Parlamento russo), ou o atual primeiro-ministro, secundaram o líder: era preciso reconhecer a independência das "repúblicas" russófonas de
Donetsk
e
Lugansk
.
PUB
Com destaque para o momento em que o chefe dos serviços de espionagem, Sergei Naryshkin, pareceu fugir ao guião pré-estabelecido, dando um passo adicional, para defender a integração, pura e simples, das duas regiões na
Rússia
(a exemplo do que aconteceu, em 2014, com a península da Crimeia e com a cidade autónoma de Sebastopol, sede da frota russa do Mar Negro). Putin corrigiu o espião e lembrou-lhe que o que estava em discussão era a independência, não a anexação. É difícil de acreditar que tenha sido apenas um passo em falso.
Ainda a
União Europeia
e os
EUA
anunciavam a convocação apressada dos seus próprios conselhos e já Putin preparava o próximo passo, numa sucessão de acontecimentos a ritmo invulgar. O espanhol Josep Borrell anunciava, no final de um Conselho Europeu de ministros dos Negócios Estrangeiros, que levaria para cima da mesa, nos próximos dias, um conjunto de propostas de sanções. Os norte-americanos, mais expeditos (e beneficiando da diferença horária)
já anunciavam um pacote de punições
, ainda que exclusivamente dirigidas aos dois territórios e a quem porventura por ali pretenda investir nos próximos tempos. Mas quem no seu juízo o faria?
O presidente russo, sempre um passo à frente da concorrência (é, normalmente, uma espécie de prerrogativa do agressor), já discursava na televisão, anunciado ao povo que a história está do lado dos russos (não sem antes avisar das suas intenções, por telefone, o presidente Macron e o chanceler Scholtz, tentando dessa forma transformá-los numa espécie de idiotas úteis). Porque a Ucrânia, segundo Putin, é uma invenção dos bolcheviques russos, em particular de Lenine. E transformou-se, nos últimos anos, numa "colónia" do Ocidente dirigida por um "Governo fantoche". Resumindo, um Estado sem direito histórico à existência.
E não tardou que surgissem as notícias sobre o passo seguinte - enviar os militares russos para as repúblicas populares de
Donetsk
e
Lugansk
, em "missão de paz". Com um alerta em tons sinistros: se Kiev não puser um fim à violência no Leste da Ucrânia, será então responsável pelo "banho de sangue" subsequente. Americanos e europeus vão ser obrigados a atualizar, ainda hoje, um pacote de sanções que deixaram de fazer sentido ainda antes de serem aplicadas. Porque, como dizia Pimenta Machado, o que hoje é verdade, amanhã pode ser mentira. No futebol como na política internacional
Rafael Barbosa

The day began with promises of peace and ended with the sound of war drums. Emmanuel Macron was close to achieving a summit between Putin and Biden, but the Russian president imposed a very different script. A few hours after the death of diplomacy, he recognized the independence of the two separatist regions of Eastern Ukraine and ordered the sending of troops to the Donetsk and Lugansk regions.
The sending of the Russian army to Ukraine is, in the words of
Vladimir Putin
, a
"peacekeeping operation"
. It is not known how many of the approximately 200,000 soldiers stationed near the Ukrainian border (in
Russia
and in
Belarus
) received marching orders. And it is also not known with what final objective: whether they are simply going to ensure "peace" in the part of the Ukrainian Donbass already controlled by the separatists, whether they are moving towards the conquest of the territory of the self-proclaimed people's republics of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
still in the hands of the Ukrainian army. It could be the difference between starting the death count immediately or not.
Be aware of the short lifespan of any news or analysis regarding the Ukraine conflict. The first few shots will be enough for everything to change again. As the last 24 hours demonstrate. Which even began with a renewed promise of peace, or at least negotiation, following the French president's efforts. Macron occupied Sunday night and Monday morning with successive phone calls to
Vladimir Putin
, then to
Joe Biden
, and again for the Russian autocrat.
In the end, and still in the early hours of Monday, Paris announced that
a summit on European security was underway
, with the leaders of the two military superpowers as the main protagonists (and only that, since, in economic terms, the
Russia
is worth considerably less than half a dozen countries and incomparably less than
USA
). The trumpets of peace sounded for a short time. To American distrust,
the Russian warning came: it is premature to speak at a summit
. It was realized a few hours later that the script had already been written. And that Putin did not intend to deviate even one millimeter from his war games.
The most significant moment of the day would end up being the meeting of the Russian National Security Council. An evident staging, allegedly on live television (journalists who watched it live admit as quite likely the hypothesis that it was a previously recorded moment), which served mainly for the Russian autocrat to commit the most important members of his Government to what would follow.
With greater or lesser enthusiasm, figures such as Dimitri Medvedev (who alternated, at Putin's orders, as prime minister and president, until he achieved the constitutional changes that perpetuate him in power), the president of the Duma (the Russian Parliament), or the current prime minister, supported the leader: it was necessary to recognize the independence of the Russian-speaking "republics" of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
.
PUB
With emphasis on the moment when the head of the espionage services, Sergei Naryshkin, seemed to deviate from the pre-established script, taking an additional step, to defend the integration, pure and simple, of the two regions in the
Russia
(like what happened, in 2014, with the Crimean peninsula and the autonomous city of Sevastopol, headquarters of the Russian Black Sea Fleet). Putin corrected the spy and reminded him that what was under discussion was independence, not annexation. It's hard to believe it was just a misstep.
Still the
European Union
and the
USA
they announced the hasty convening of their own councils and Putin was already preparing the next step, in a succession of events at an unusual pace. Spaniard Josep Borrell announced, at the end of a European Council of Foreign Affairs ministers, that he would bring to the table, in the coming days, a set of sanctions proposals. North Americans, more expeditious (and benefiting from the time difference)
already announced a package of punishments
, although exclusively aimed at the two territories and anyone who may wish to invest there in the near future. But who in their right mind would do that?
The Russian president, always one step ahead of the competition (it is normally a kind of prerogative of the aggressor), was already speaking on television, announcing to the people that history is on the side of the Russians (not without first informing President Macron and Chancellor Scholtz of his intentions by telephone, thus trying to transform them into a kind of useful idiots). Because Ukraine, according to Putin, is an invention of the Russian Bolsheviks, in particular Lenin. And it has become, in recent years, a "colony" of the West run by a "puppet Government". In short, a State with no historical right to existence.
And it didn't take long for news to emerge about the next step - sending the Russian military to the people's republics of
Donetsk
and
Lugansk
, in "peace mission". With a warning in ominous tones: if Kiev does not put an end to the violence in Eastern Ukraine, it will then be responsible for the subsequent “bloodbath”. Americans and Europeans will be forced to update, even today, a package of sanctions that stopped making sense even before they were applied. Because, as Pimenta Machado said, what is true today, tomorrow could be a lie. In football and in international politics

title: Putin garante não ter inteno de reconstruir um império
original_title: Putin garante não ter intenção de reconstruir um império — DNOTICIAS.PT
translated_title: Putin guarantees he has no intention of rebuilding an empire — DNOTICIAS.PT
original_text:
Mundo
Putin garante não ter intenção de reconstruir um império
Agência Lusa
22 fev 2022
14:20
0
Comentários
O Presidente russo, Vladimir Putin, garantiu hoje não ter intenção de reconstruir um império, um dia depois de reconhecer territórios separatistas pró-Rússia na Ucrânia e de fazer um discurso a negar a legitimidade do Estado ucraniano.
"Antecipámos que haveria especulações de que a Rússia se estaria a preparar para reconstituir um império", afirmou, durante uma reunião no Kremlin com o seu homólogo azeri, Ilham Aliev.
"Essa não é a realidade", assegurou.
Segundo o Presidente russo, após a queda da União Soviética a Rússia "reconheceu as novas realidades e trabalhou ativamente para fortalecer" a cooperação com outros países ex-soviéticos, citando como exemplos os Estados vizinhos do Azerbaijão e do Cazaquistão.
A Ucrânia está numa "situação diferente" porque "o território deste país é utilizado por países terceiros para ameaçar a Rússia", argumentou Putin.
Além de reconhecer os separatistas pró-Rússia na Ucrânia na segunda-feira, a Rússia reconheceu dois territórios separatistas na Geórgia (2008), anexou a península da Crimeia na Ucrânia (2014) e apoiou o separatismo da Transnístria (oficialmente República Moldávia Peridniestriana) no início dos anos 1990.
Na noite de segunda-feira, Putin fez um longo e ameaçador discurso, no qual negou a legitimidade do Estado ucraniano em geral e insistiu em apresentar a Ucrânia como um país artificial e inseparável da Rússia.
O chefe de Estado russo assinou os decretos reconhecendo a independência das autoproclamadas repúblicas de Lugansk e de Donetsk, no Donbass (leste da Ucrânia), e permitiu a entrada das forças armadas russas naqueles territórios ucranianos numa missão de "manutenção da paz".
A decisão de Putin foi condenada pela generalidade dos países ocidentais, que já anunciaram ou estão a preparar sanções económicas contra a Rússia.
Hoje, o ministro da Defesa ucraniano, Oleksiy Reznikov, alertou para o objetivo russo de reconstituir a União Soviética.
"O Kremlin deu mais um passo para ressuscitar a União Soviética" através de "um novo Pacto de Varsóvia", o pacto militar criado em resposta à NATO e "um novo muro de Berlim", acusou.

World
Putin says he has no intention of rebuilding an empire
Lusa Agency
Feb 22, 2022
14:20
0
Comments
Russian President Vladimir Putin assured today that he had no intention of rebuilding an empire, one day after recognizing pro-Russian separatist territories in Ukraine and giving a speech denying the legitimacy of the Ukrainian state.
"We anticipated that there would be speculation that Russia was preparing to reconstitute an empire," he said, during a meeting in the Kremlin with his Azerbaijani counterpart, Ilham Aliev.
“That’s not reality,” he assured.
According to the Russian President, after the fall of the Soviet Union, Russia "recognized the new realities and actively worked to strengthen" cooperation with other ex-Soviet countries, citing the neighboring states of Azerbaijan and Kazakhstan as examples.
Ukraine is in a "different situation" because "the territory of this country is used by third countries to threaten Russia", Putin argued.
In addition to recognizing pro-Russian separatists in Ukraine on Monday, Russia recognized two separatist territories in Georgia (2008), annexed Ukraine's Crimean peninsula (2014), and supported separatism in Transnistria (officially the Peridniestrian Moldavian Republic) in the early 1990s.
On Monday night, Putin gave a long and threatening speech, in which he denied the legitimacy of the Ukrainian state in general and insisted on presenting Ukraine as an artificial country inseparable from Russia.
The Russian head of state signed the decrees recognizing the independence of the self-proclaimed republics of Lugansk and Donetsk, in Donbass (eastern Ukraine), and allowed the Russian armed forces to enter those Ukrainian territories on a "peacekeeping" mission.
Putin's decision was condemned by most Western countries, which have already announced or are preparing economic sanctions against Russia.

Quais são as regiões separatistas da Ucrânia?
Relacionados
ONU.
ONU diz que reconhecimento dos separatistas viola soberania da Ucrânia
Análise.
Rússia faz soar os tambores da guerra na Ucrânia
Donetsk e Lugansk (a região do Donbass) separaram-se da Ucrânia em 2014 (no mesmo ano, a Rússia anexou a península da Crimeia e a cidade de Sebastopol) e proclamaram a independência das suas "repúblicas populares". O regime de Vladimir Putin garantiu a viabilidade dos dois territórios através de ajuda militar, auxílio financeiro e, até, nos anos da pandemia, com vacinas contra a covid-19, transformando-as, na prática, em estados satélites da Federação Russa.
Existe alguma ligação entre estas regiões e Portugal?
A principal cidade do Donbass é Donetsk. Para os portugueses mais atentos ao fenómeno futebolístico, Donetsk é um nome familiar, por causa do principal clube de futebol da cidade, o Shaktar, que já foi treinado por dois portugueses: Paulo Fonseca (2016 a 2019) e Luís Castro (2019-2020). A cidade foi também uma das sedes do Euro 2012.
Que relação tem o Donbass com Moscovo e quem lá vive?
Até agora, Moscovo entendia que as duas regiões faziam parte da Ucrânia, mesmo que a Rússia fosse o único garante da viabilidade política dos líderes separatistas de Lugansk e Donetsk. De forma oficiosa, eram já uma espécie de províncias russas. Aqui viverão, ainda, cerca de três milhões de pessoas, ou seja, cerca de metade da população de antes da guerra iniciada em 2014. Cerca de 800 mil dos seus habitantes têm passaporte russo.
PUB
O que são os acordos de Minsk e porque falharam?
Na sequência da anexação da Crimeia e da guerra civil no Donbass, foram assinados dois acordos. O primeiro, ainda em 2014, estabelecia um cessar-fogo entre o exército ucraniano e os separatistas russos. O segundo, assinado em 2015, continha uma espécie de guião para a paz. Que nunca foi cumprido. Moscovo defende que o acordo estabelece a autonomia alargada das repúblicas de Donetsk e Lugansk e até o direito de veto em questões nacionais (por exemplo, no caso de pedidos de adesão à União Europeia ou à NATO). Os ucranianos sustentam que o que foi acordado foi uma autonomia mitigada e que, antes de ser aplicada, é obrigatório o desarmamento das milícias russas e a passagem do controlo das fronteiras para o Estado central. Posições contraditórias que ditaram que um caminho para a paz se transformasse num beco sem saída.
A Rússia já reconheceu outras repúblicas separatistas?
Nada disto é novo, a diferença está na dimensão, uma vez que a Ucrânia é um país gigantesco onde vivem mais de 40 milhões de pessoas. Em 2008, depois de um breve conflito militar com a Geórgia, outra ex-república soviética que pretendia escapar aos ditames do Kremlin, os russos reconheceram a independência da Ossétia do Sul e da Abkhazia. Garantem, desde então, apoio financeiro aos separatistas, cidadania russa às populações e a de defesa contra as investidas do Estado georgiano, com a permanência de milhares de tropas nas duas "repúblicas". O objetivo (então, como agora na Ucrânia), é impedir o controlo do território e com isso bloquear qualquer tentação da Geórgia em aderir, por exemplo, à NATO.

What are the breakaway regions of Ukraine?

Analysis.
Russia sounds the drums of war in Ukraine
Donetsk and Lugansk (the Donbass region) separated from Ukraine in 2014 (in the same year, Russia annexed the Crimean peninsula and the city of Sevastopol) and proclaimed the independence of their "people's republics". Vladimir Putin's regime guaranteed the viability of the two territories through military aid, financial assistance and, even, during the pandemic years, with vaccines against Covid-19, transforming them, in practice, into satellite states of the Russian Federation.
Is there any connection between these regions and Portugal?
The main city in Donbass is Donetsk. For those Portuguese who are most aware of the football phenomenon, Donetsk is a familiar name, because of the city's main football club, Shaktar, which was coached by two Portuguese: Paulo Fonseca (2016 to 2019) and Luís Castro (2019-2020). The city was also one of the venues for Euro 2012.
What relationship does Donbass have with Moscow and who lives there?
Until now, Moscow understood that the two regions were part of Ukraine, even though Russia was the only guarantor of the political viability of the separatist leaders of Luhansk and Donetsk. Unofficially, they were already a kind of Russian provinces. Around three million people will still live here, that is, around half of the population before the war that began in 2014. Around 800,000 of its inhabitants have a Russian passport.
PUB
What are the Minsk agreements and why did they fail?
Following the annexation of Crimea and the civil war in Donbass, two agreements were signed. The first, still in 2014, established a ceasefire between the Ukrainian army and Russian separatists. The second, signed in 2015, contained a kind of roadmap for peace. Which was never fulfilled. Moscow argues that the agreement establishes the expanded autonomy of the republics of Donetsk and Luhansk and even the right of veto on national issues (for example, in the case of requests for membership in the European Union or NATO). The Ukrainians maintain that what was agreed was a mitigated autonomy and that, before it is applied, the disarmament of the Russian militias and the transfer of border control to the central state are mandatory. Contradictory positions that dictated that a path to peace turned into a dead end.
Has Russia recognized other breakaway republics?
None of this is new, the difference is in size, since Ukraine is a gigantic country where more than 40 million people live. In 2008, after a brief military conflict with Georgia, another former Soviet republic that sought to escape the Kremlin's dictates, the Russians recognized the independence of South Ossetia and Abkhazia. Since then, they have guaranteed financial support for the separatists, Russian citizenship for the populations and defense against the attacks of the Georgian State, with the presence of thousands of troops in the two "republics". The objective (then, as now in Ukraine), is to prevent control of the territory and thereby block any temptation for Georgia to join, for example, NATO.
